question: Thank you. He can get the beer.
answer: Rutaganda's place?

question: What's wrong?
answer: Beg your pardon sir, you are Hutu. You are safe there.

question: You are with me, Zozo, don't worry. Zozo throws the van into gear and speeds off.
answer: What is it like to fly on a plane, sir?

question: It depends where you sit Zozo. In coach it is like the bus to Giterama.
answer: That is why they call it coach?

question: Maybe. But in business class there are fine wines, linens, Belgian chocolates.
answer: You have taken business class?

question: Many times. Turn off.
answer: There is nowhere to turn, sir. As the van approaches,

question: Slow down. Boys, do you know the way to Mr. Rutagunda's warehouse? This is thirsty work, let me treat you to some beers.
answer: You will join us at the rally today?

question: I will try my best George but these days I have no time for rallies or politics.
answer: Politics is power, Paul. And money.

question: Time is money, George. We need extra beer today.
answer: Business is good at the hotel?

question: Very good.
answer: I am always glad to see you Paul. Hell man, that is not beer, put it back! Forget the Carlsberg, give him Grolsch. I won't charge extra.

question: Thank you.
answer: A bargain buy, from China. Ten cents each, I'll get a dollar.

question: Mr. Ambassador, please come in.
answer: Thank you, Paul.

question: Colonel Oliver, you are very welcome. The Ambassador shakes the Colonel's hand.
answer: Colonel. I'd like you to meet Mr. Colson, of our Regional Aid Division. Colonel Oliver is the liason officer for the U.N. peace keeping forces.

question: Paul, Paul, a moment please.
answer: Yes, Benedict, what can I do?

question: Can you get me into the Ambassador's reception?
answer: I'm sorry, it's a private function.

question: At least tell me who is attending. The newspaper will be grateful.
answer: I will be grateful if you keep my name out of your newspaper. Wait here and you will see who has attended as they leave.

question: No. You pick it up. How are your dish-washing skills, Gregoire? Gregoire, there are no cockroaches in this hotel, do you understand?
answer: Cockroaches? Don't tell me we have cockroaches, Paul? A sly smile breaks on Gregoire's face as he uses Bik's arrival to disappear inside.

question: No, Bik, it's a code word for Tutsis.
answer: That's what I came to talk to you about.

question: Excuse me?
answer: The Hutu-Tutsi thing. The BBC faxed to say they would be here on the sixth for the peace accords. And the U.N. wants the banquet room for that day, a reception to broadcast the signing ceremony. Can you organize monitors and check the satellite dish?

question: Leave it to me.
answer: Also, could you remember to use the service entrance at all times?

question: My best to Jean Baptiste. Thomas wants advice?
answer: He wants your wisdom.

question: Let's have dinner first.
answer: Of course.

question: Hello, Anais. She laughs. You are not Anais? Oh, Carine, that is a shame. I have a present for Anais. Goodness, I cannot tell. I guess I must find another present. Roger, your turn.
answer: For food and clothes, and all that grows, etc, etc. Dear Lord, thank you.

question: Thank you, Roger. Why the hurry, Roger?
answer: Simon has a new pet. Can I go see it?

question: What is it? Oh, my God, it's Victor. Why do they want Victor? Do something.
answer: What?

question: Call your friends in the army. Call someone. Victor is harmless. This is a mistake.
answer: Please, be quiet.

question: I'm going to talk to them.
answer: No.

question: We must do something.
answer: What would you have us do? Argue with these madmen? We cannot interfere. You better stay the night, it is too dangerous to be on the streets.

question: I'll fix a bed. Why didn't you call your contacts in the army?
answer: I couldn't help.

question: You could have asked for a favor.
answer: No, I could not. What do you know about favors Tatiana, about barter and deals? All day long I work to please this officer, that diplomat, this tourist. To store up favors so that if there is a time when my family need help I have powerful people I can call upon. Now you would have me waste a precious favor on a stranger.

question: Victor was not a stranger, he was our neighbor.
answer: He was not family. Family is all that matters. Do you think if you or I were being dragged from here, any one of them would lift a finger to help us?

question: They do not have your connections.
answer: Connections? I have no connections, only favors. If I call to help Victor, a General will think "Paul Rusesabagina is a fool. He thinks my favors are so numerous and so insignificant as to waste them on everybody." Then my hard work is doubly squandered. I insult the General and I do not get to use my favor at all. Please leave these things to my good judgment.

question: Paul, how the hell are ya'?
answer: I am delighted to see you, Mr. Daglish.

question: They moved you from the Diplomat?
answer: Promoted. House Manager.

question: Good for you.
answer: Let me check. Ah, I see the mistake. You were reading CBC - the Canadian broadcasting people instead of BBC Gregoire.

question: Of course.
answer: Did you bring any of those wee girls who used to sit at the bar in the Diplomat with you? You know?

question: I'm sorry, Mr. Daglish, this is the Mille Collines. No working girls here.
answer: Can we phone them in, Paul?

question: I'm afraid I can't do that, Mr. Daglish. Ah, Zozo. You remember Zozo, from the Diplomat?
answer: Zozo! The very man!

question: Excuse me, gentlemen.
answer: Forgive us, Paul. We must talk.

question: What's wrong?
answer: We are leaving Rwanda, Paul.

question: Go to the terrace, I will join you.
answer: My assistant, the Hutu Power man, says we should get out now, that soon it will be very bad.

question: Give me this man's name.
answer: His name is Naramaranga, but please, Paul, even though he is Hutu Power, he is a friend, he likes me. He told me there is a signal. It is "Cut the tall trees." When they hear the signal, the militia are to go to war.

question: Thomas, Fedens, I am a man who looks after his family. If there were danger I would be the first to leave? Calm yourself, it is fireworks to celebrate the peace.
answer: Please, Paul, tomorrow I will bring you my car. You will sell it for me and get a fair price. We will go to Tanzania until there is real peace.

question: ello. Tatsi. Yes, they are here. Yes. I know but I want them to calm down. Already the press are packing their bags. The BBC man told me there's no story here. We are boring now. I'll be home soon. Let us all go home and sleep. Call when you get home. And don't worry, Thomas. Good night. Pealiss!
answer: Paul!

question: Jean Baptiste! What is going on?
answer: The president has been murdered.

question: Nonsense. Why would the rebels kill the president when he agreed to peace?
answer: Where are Thomas and Fedens?

question: I sent them home. Go and call them.
answer: I tried already. The phones do not work.

question: Come on, everyone out of this room, find a seat in the living room. Is every Tutsi in the neighborhood here?
answer: They came through the bushes, over the wall. What could I do?

question: Send them home. We are not the police. What do we have to protect them?
answer: Please. Let them stay 'til morning. The militia will not come here, they know you are a Hutu with influence.

question: They know you are Tutsi!
answer: Please, Paul, 'til first light.

question: Where are you hurt, son?
answer: Get his clothes off.

question: What happened, son? Where did you get this blood?
answer: He's not injured.

question: Leave us, give us some space. The neighbors must go at dawn.
answer: Will you take a little milk?

question: Let him sleep. It is time for the neighbors to leave. Shut up!
answer: What is it, Paul.

question: Stay with the children. Who is in charge?
answer: Who are you?

question: I am Paul Rusesabagina, a good friend of General Bizimungu.
answer: We are looking for you.

question: What is this about?
answer: Let me see your identity card. You heard the Tutsi cockroaches murdered our president.

question: Yes, it is a calamity for us all.
answer: You work at the Hotel Diplomat?

question: No. I work at the Mille Collines. I used to work at the Diplomat.
answer: Do you know how to open the safe there? Our government needs to use the hotel and the room keys are in the safe. You must open it.

question: Of course. Captain, I must take my family. It is not safe here.
answer: Where is your family?

question: Where is your family?
answer: This is them.

question: All of them! I cannot take them.
answer: No, no, good Captain, you do not have to. We have the car and our van.

question: Let's go.
answer: Don't look. The safe is in the manager's office.

question: Go with him, get the keys.
answer: Gentlemen, you'll find some chocolate, and maybe a few beers in the fridge. Don't let them go to waste. I've got them.

question: Traitor! They are all Tutsi cockroaches.
answer: Let me explain.

question: SHOOT THEM!
answer: Please, I don't use guns.

question: There is nothing to it. Shoot them now or you die first.
answer: Captain, what could I pay you not to do this?

question: You want to pay me?
answer: Why not? These are not rebels, look at them. Soon they will be worthless to you. Why not take some money, for your work?

question: How much?
answer: Name a price.

question: Ten thousand francs for each one.
answer: I don't have that much. Wait! Wait! Here, here, a thousand US dollars - fifty thousand francs for my family. To let us drive off to the Mille Collines.

question: How many in your family?
answer: Six. Have you any money?

question: Get in. Captain, let these people give you some money, whatever they have. Give me everything, everything you have.
answer: There is only enough for one cockroach. Pick one to take with you.

question: Wait, wait. Ten.
answer: And four children?

question: I'll give you a hundred thousand francs for all of them.
answer: Give me it.

question: I don't have it here. At the Mille Collines. I can get it for you.
answer: You will run into the hotel and hide behind the U.N.

question: I swear, Captain, one hundred thousand francs, enough for a house. I will get the money, you keep them outside.
answer: I will keep your family outside. Let's go. Go with my soldiers. And hurry back if you want to keep these cockroaches.

question: Please, I am the house manager. Return in thirty minutes and we will deal with all your requests, thank you. What happened to all the rooms? Take this room. Tatiana, bring the children.
answer: What about them?

question: Them. They almost got us all killed. I have done enough for them! We cannot look after them anymore.
answer: What are you going to do? You cannot drive them out onto the road. They can stay with me.

question: What!
answer: I will not have them on my conscience. They will stay in my room.

question: Can I help you? What is his room number? Go downstairs, I will help you. What are you doing?
answer: Trying Thomas and Fedens. We've got to get them here.

question: This won't do.
answer: It will do just fine.

question: Any luck?
answer: No answer. Please send someone to get them, please.

question: Terrible times, Paul. There are bodies everywhere. I cannot stay here.
answer: I need a great favor. I need you to go to this address and bring my brother-in-law and his family.

question: No, no. This is a very dangerous part of town. I cannot do this.
answer: This would be an enormous favor to me. I am a man of means, Mr. Garandi. When this nonsense is over I will be most grateful.

question: What!
answer: Mr. Manager.

question: Gregoire, what are you doing here?
answer: What do you want?

question: Get out of this room and get back to work.
answer: I don't have to listen to you anymore.

question: I am in charge now. Get back to work or I'll fire you.
answer: Let me ask you Mr. Manager, do you notice a smell of cockroaches? If I were to leave this room, I'm sure I could find this smell. I know people who could cleanse it. But maybe it doesn't bother you? Why is that? Are used to this smell? Not me, I need a clean room to escape it.

question: Do we know who fired the missile that killed the president?
answer: No. But I fear it's intention may have been to kill the peace accords and spark a civil war between the Hutu Militia and the Tutsi rebels.

question: We've heard reports of reprisal killings. Will the UN intervene to stop the bloodshed.?
answer: Unfortunately we're here as peace-keepers not peace makers, we can't take an aggressive role.

question: If the UN changes your mandate could you stop the bloodshed?
answer: Yes. With some re-inforcements I'm confident we could impose order.

question: Have you requested re-enforcements?
answer: Yes we have.

question: What was the response?
answer: We're awaiting a decision, excuse me. Paul, I've sent my soldiers to rescue the Lady Prime Minister, she'll need a room.

question: Paul Rusesabagina, Mr. Godefroid. The house manager. I met you on your last visit.
answer: Yes, Paul, I remember. The Mille Collines is a very important property for Sabena. Our directors believe we should close down, shutter the place until this unrest is over?

question: Sir, that would be very bad for our reputation. We are an oasis of calm for all our loyal customers. What would they think if Sabena deserted them now? I assure you the United Nations has everything under control.
answer: Very well. But if this thing gets worse, we must close. If there's anything you need, call anytime.

question: Has Roger spoken yet?
answer: No, Odette says he's in shock.

question: How can we help him.
answer: He needs to be in a safe place. Have you heard from Mr. Garindi?

question: Hey Peter, hook me back into the monitors. Holy shit! Holy shit.
answer: What is it?

question: You fucking see that!
answer: Oh my God! It's Gloria. Listen we've footage, unbelievable footage! A massacre! Machetes, murderers, dead bodies. You have to lead with this. We'll send it through right now. Wait 'til you see this.

question: Here, have a sandwich.
answer: Fuck you.

question: You have a battalion, you could stop this now. The Hutu army is no match for you. You will remember this day for the rest of your lives.
answer: Colonel, what can I get you? Paul gets behind the bar.

question: Anything. Strong.
answer: Canadian Club? Congratulations, Colonel. You have saved us all.

question: Congratulations. You should spit in my face.
answer: Excuse me, Colonel.

question: We think you are dirt, less than dirt, worthless.
answer: I don't understand.

question: Don't bullshit me, Paul. You're the smartest man here. You have them all eating out of your hand. You'd own this fucking hotel, except for one thing. You're fucking black! You're not even a nigger, you're African! They're not staying to stop this thing. They're gonna fly right out of here with their people.
answer: Their people?

question: They're only taking the whites.
answer: Children, go into the hallway. Please, go.

question: Children, go into the hallway. Please, go.
answer: What's wrong?

question: All the whites are leaving. They are being evacuated.
answer: What about us?

question: We have been abandoned.
answer: The soldiers will stop the killers.

question: Listen to me woman. I said all the whites are leaving. The French, the Italians, even the Belgian UN soldiers.
answer: But who is left?

question: I don't know. Colonel Oliver says the UN has three hundred soldiers for the whole country. Black soldiers, Pakistanis. The most the Colonel can spare for the hotel are four men, and they're not allowed to shoot. If anything should happen, if the Militia arrive, you must take the children and go to the roof.
answer: What for?

question: Darlin', believe me, if I could... Here. Here. Give her what she wants, room, food, anything. Charge it all. Don't you put her out, Paul.
answer: I would never do that.

question: I know that, Paul. I'm sorry. Here take this.
answer: This is a Rolex, I can't take it.

question: Open up the ballroom, we'll put them there. And Zozo tell the kitchen to make rice and beans - a lot of it.
answer: You could leave, Paul.

question: What are you saying, Tatsi?
answer: Your card says Hutu. Take our children, go and get the twins, pay money at the roadblocks. Get them out. Please.

question: Enough of this. We stay together. Let me rest, I will feel better then.
answer: You are the manager?

question: Yes, sir. What is wrong?
answer: Everyone must leave the hotel now.

question: Why sir?
answer: It's an order. Get everyone out now.

question: I...ah...need some time. Please give us twenty, thirty minutes. People are sleeping. Please, have some cold drinks. I will be as quick as I can.
answer: We will be outside, ten minutes.

question: Good day, General Bizimungu please. Do you know where he is? Please ask him to call Paul Rusesabagina. It is urgent. Colonel Bagsora. Where? Can you find him? Who would order such a thing? Did you find the General?
answer: If British Airways abandons the route we should bid for it. Paul. Are you alright?

question: We have a big problem. The Hutu army have come and ordered us all of us out of the hotel. I do not know, sir. I think they will kill us all.
answer: All. What do you mean all?

question: The staff, the guests.
answer: The staff and guests! How many?

question: Now we have eight hundred guests and one hundred staff. I have ten minutes left. I wish I could have done more, sir. Please, thank all my friends at Sabena. You have been good to me and my family.
answer: Paul, wait, wait, I'm going to put you on hold for one minute, stay on the phone.

question: Paul, wait, wait, I'm going to put you on hold for one minute, stay on the phone.
answer: Paul listens to music on the phone.

question: Get the prime minister's office. Call General Chareaux. Louis get the UN. Tell them this is Belgian property.
answer: The music is suddenly interrupted.

question: Paul, are you there?
answer: Yes, thank you Mr. President.

question: Paul, if you have one call in all the world to stop this, who would you call?
answer: The French. They supply the Rwandan army.

question: Where's the guest list? Anderson, Arthurs, Boulier. What is this?
answer: The guest list. It hasn't been updated since the murder of the president.

question: Are you trying to make a fool of me? There are no Europeans left in that hotel. Get me the names of all the cockroaches in there.
answer: That will take time.

question: You don't have time. If I do not have the names, so that I can pick out the traitors, then I will kill everyone here in this car park. Get in there now. Hey you, come here. Who did you call?
answer: Call, sir?

question: Don't lie to me. What's your name?
answer: Rusesabagina. Paul Rusesabagina.

question: I will remember that name. Let's go.
answer: They have gone.

question: They are gone. Thank you, sir. What did you do?
answer: I managed to get the President of France on the phone.

question: Thank you, sir, you saved our lives.
answer: Paul, I pleaded with the president to go in and get you all. He told me it will not happen.

question: Why?
answer: I can give you many political answers Paul but the truth is that Africa is not worth a single vote to all of them You have to get out of there, Paul. I will do whatever I can.

question: Go with Zozo to the ballroom. We will find you bedding. This is a hotel. No one will be allowed to stay in the lobby. Good. I want you to go around and take all the numbers off the doors. Nothing. I want no numbers on the doors. Good day. Here is your bill for the last week. If you cannot pay, or think you will not be able to pay, go to the ballroom. Zozo will take care of you.
answer: Come in Paul.

question: I'm afraid you will have to move room.
answer: Move? Where to?

question: I'm going to put you on the third floor.
answer: The third floor are low class rooms.

question: Yes they are. However if the army return they will expect important people such as yourself to be in these grand rooms.
answer: Pack the bags, we have to move.

question: I am glad you are well.
answer: I'm sorry it is not Glenmorangie.

question: As long as it is scotch. Your white friends have abandoned you, Paul.
answer: The United Nations are still here.

question: The United Nations. Madmen are on the streets, Paul. But I will take care of you. Your cellar is well-stocked, right?
answer: Yes, General. I am glad you came by. I overheard something that I think you should know about.

question: What did you overhear?
answer: A discussion between an American Embassy official and a UN Colonel.

question: What did they say?
answer: The American assured the colonel that they would watch everything.

question: Watch everything? How? They are gone.
answer: Satellites.

question: Satellites?
answer: Yes, they can photograph the epaulets on your shoulder. The American said intervention is too costly, better to get photographic evidence and snatch up the high command.

question: The high command? Our high command?
answer: 'Snatch them up and put on a war crimes trial. Lock them all away forever. No political risk, and big publicity.' That's what he said. I thought I'd better tell you.

question: The Americans! Who are they to put us on trial. Let us imagine Paul when their president Kennedy was shot, they said it was a black man. Then their politicians, their radio stations gave orders `we must wipe out these black people before they wipe out us.' What do you think would have happened? No different.
answer: Indeed, general. Excuse me momentarily. Where has all our beer gone?

question: Indeed, general. Excuse me momentarily. Where has all our beer gone?
answer: Sir, Gregoire has been taking beers.

question: How much beer?
answer: Many beers.

question: I am worried about thieves and criminals coming into the hotel. Perhaps you could arrange for some police to guard us.
answer: The police are very busy.

question: I understand General, but when I last talked to the president of Sabena he promised me that anyone who helped protect Belgian property would be rewarded.
answer: He did.

question: "Well rewarded" Those were his words.
answer: If I were to spare a few policemen, where would I station them?

question: The front gate would be best, General. They could check all guests.
answer: I will see what I can do.

question: I admire you, General. How do you keep command of your men amidst such madness?
answer: I am strong, Paul, like a lion.

question: I wish I were like you. Look at my staff, they won't work, they listen to no one.
answer: Get to work, you slug. Make sure, Paul, your guests are generous.

question: Yes. Why not?
answer: That is not true.

question: I confess. It's true I have a deal with General Bizimungu. He was just here. I worked out another money making scheme for him. New arrivals will be taxed at the gate. Do you know what my deal is with Bizimungu. I pay him and he keeps you alive. Anyone want to take their money back? Here, here take it. And you don't have to pay your bill. I will move you into the ballroom or out into the gardens. And, yes, I work with George Rutagunda. I buy rice and beans, beer and soap. I will have to visit his warehouse soon because we are running out of food. Who wants to come with me? Anyone who wants to come with me stay behind. If not, please leave. You are most certainly not coming with me. You will get me killed. George will not hurt me, I am too profitable to him.
answer: What if he is not there?

question: As soon as the General left he came running back. Help me, sir, I have been possessed by a witch. A witch you say? Yes, yes, I did not know I was in that room. The president's room, why would I be in the president's room? Indeed, the General asked me the same. Asked you what? Does Gregoire think he is president now?
answer: Stop, stop, we will waken the children.

question: Lynch Bages, 84. Perfect with lamb, or fine rare beef.
answer: So where is the lamb?

question: Maybe Gregoire and the witch ate it.
answer: What's the matter?

question: We're running out of beer and other supplies.
answer: The foreigners abandon us and you do inventory. You are so conscientious.

question: I have to go out to get food.
answer: Go out! Where?

question: To Rutagunda's place. It is close by.
answer: No, no.

question: I have to, Tatiana, we are only as valuable as the service we provide.
answer: You cannot go alone.

question: Please, except my humblest apologies...
answer: Don't worry. I have a job this morning. I must go to visit my good friend George Rutagunda. You know George? Fetch the van.

question: Where are we going, sir?
answer: For supplies, you drive.

question: The fog is too heavy, sir.
answer: Just drive, Gregoire.

question: We should go back, sir.
answer: Hello? Let's go.

question: Hello? Let's go.
answer: What do you want?

question: We are to meet Mr. Rutagunda.
answer: The commander is not here.

question: He will be here.
answer: Show me your ID

question: Excuse me.
answer: What?

question: Our cards, please.
answer: What cards?

question: You have our cards.
answer: No. But I make cards. Would you like me to make you two cards?

question: How much?
answer: One thousand francs.

question: Paul. My old friend. Everything is double the price now, you do understand that?
answer: I need rice, beans, beer, and your best whiskey. G You have no whiskey?

question: No whiskey, no spirits. Your rich cockroaches at the hotel, they will have to do without their scotch. Anyway, I have bled that cow enough Paul.
answer: What do you mean George?

question: Their money is no good to them. Soon all the Ineysi will be dead.
answer: ) You cannot kill them all.

question: Why not? We are half way there already.
answer: Let's go.

question: Take the river road back. It is clear.
answer: Are you sure this is the river road?

question: Stop. You've driven off the road. You'll put us in the river. Go back! Go back! Tell no one what you saw, do you understand? That's a big one. Here we go. Roger, you have no greeting for me. There, do not worry, no tears.
answer: Where are we going? Please, Paul, why do we have to go to the roof?

question: It's alright. This is the only place I can find some peace.
answer: I hear we must pay for everything. How much for this?

question: A kiss.
answer: You are a very good man, Paul Rusesabagina.

question: I have a confession. When we met...
answer: In Ruhengeri?

question: Yes, when you worked as the nurse.
answer: Yes.

question: I had you transferred to Kigali.
answer: What?

question: I bribed the Minister of Health to have you transferred to Kigali.
answer: Why?

question: To be closer. So that I could marry you.
answer: What was the bribe? What am I worth to you?

question: It was substantial.
answer: Tell me what it was.

question: A car.
answer: What sort of car?

question: What does it matter.
answer: I want to know.

question: A Volkswagen.
answer: A Volkswagen! I hope it was a new Volkswagen.

question: It is dangerous to be here. The radio says this is a nest of cockroaches.
answer: I need one last favor. Go back and get the twins.

question: No, it is impossible. That side of town has been destroyed in the fighting. The children are dead.
answer: How do you know?

question: Everyone is dead there. The dogs eat the bodies in the street. I have to go.
answer: I will give you my house. It's a fine house. Here is a paper. Madame Kawunda, please. I need you to witness this signature. Madame Kawunda is the Minister for Agriculture. She is a very reliable witness. Please witness this deed. There, now go and find them. They have no papers. No one knows they are Tutsi. They will be alive. You must be back by 7:00a.m. tomorrow. Seven, remember.

question: I will get you all visas. I promise. I will get you out of here.
answer: Ask them to wait a little longer. For the twins.

question: Get on the truck, Tatiana.
answer: No.

question: Look, our children are crying, please get on the truck. I have to stay.
answer: No! Sit down now.

question: I cannot leave these people. I will wait for the twins.
answer: Let go. Let me off this truck. Let me go. Children get off.

question: I will follow on the next plane. Go. I love you. Keep the children safe.
answer: Paul!

question: Boss, sir, quick, please, come quick. Sir, the radio, you must hear, it is on the radio.
answer: Dear lord, how did they know?

question: I saw Gregoire make a call, sir?
answer: When?

question: Come here. Where are my supplies?
answer: I'm sorry, General. The cellar is empty.

question: You have cockroaches dancing on tables and you tell me the cellar is empty? Did they drink my whiskey?
answer: No. We have no way of finding other stock but I have money for you from the guests.

question: I ran out of whiskey. Please go down and guard us. Get down there and stop them, please. Get down and stop them. What do you mean you cannot shoot? Then go and pretend you are soldiers.
answer: We are almost out of water.

question: We are almost out of everything. We had a good life, you and I. I want to make our peace. To thank God for the time we had. We have to have a plan.
answer: What sort of plan?

question: Our children cannot see us die first. If the Militia comes, you must hurry up to the roof. I will meet you there.
answer: Please do not talk like this.

question: No. It was only a storeroom. They fired a rocket at us.
answer: Yes. Where are the Rwandan police?

question: I ran out of bribes. Bizimungu took them away.
answer: That explains it. I'm sorry to tell you this but we've heard rumors the Militia are getting ready to storm the hotel.

question: Will you protect us.
answer: I can't, I don't have the men. There's one option.

question: What is it?
answer: The rebels have fought their way into the city. They have many Hutu prisoners. They're willing to exchange them for you all.

question: We'll be chopped here.
answer: A man came to my headquarters, asked that I give you this. Paul, I need you to buy me a day or two. I don't have the fuel for this convoy. I will have to scrounge it.

question: I can't. I have nothing left to bribe with. Can your men at the gate hold out for another day?
answer: No, Paul, they're afraid. They've demanded to be moved back to headquarters now.

question: Give me their uniforms. I will put people at the gate, in disguise.
answer: I wish I could, Paul. Try to hold out. One more day.

question: I have to go to the Diplomat. General, sir. I am glad to find you. I have found you some supplies.
answer: Whiskey?

question: The finest, and cognac, champagne. Come and I will get them for you.
answer: I'll be over.

question: We must go to the Diplomat.
answer: Get in.

question: Your police are at the gate?
answer: After the Diplomat!

question: Where are they going?
answer: They can go where they want. They are in charge now.

question: What do you mean, General?
answer: We have decided to move the government to Gitarama.

question: When?
answer: Today. Maggots! Do your work.

question: It might be damaged, General.
answer: Here. To celebrate. You know what the Scottish call it?

question: No.
answer: Ishca Baha - the water of life. I went on a tour once of the finest single malt distillery in the world. Have you ever been to Scotland?

question: No, sir.
answer: Wonderful country, wonderful golf. I wonder - will I ever go back? What do you think?

question: I hope we all get to do many things. Can we go now?
answer: Pack those carefully, put them in my jeep, and guard them.

question: Please, General, call and put your policemen back at the gate.
answer: I am going to do you a great favor. I am going to take you with us to Gitarama.

question: I do not want to go to Gitarama, General.
answer: You cannot go back to the hotel. The crazy men are going there now. Better to come with me.

question: The Militia are at the hotel?! We must go back now, General, please, for my family.
answer: We are better here.

question: Listen, you need me. You are a marked man.
answer: How so.

question: The Americans, and the UN they have you as a war criminal. You are on a list.
answer: I am on a list! What list?

question: When the Europeans left, their soldiers gathered lists.
answer: You lie.

question: If you do not help me, you will stay on that list.
answer: I committed no war crimes.

question: Who will tell them? You need me to tell how you helped the hotel. The others who have gone, they blame you for all their misfortune. They say you led the massacres.
answer: I led no massacres.

question: You think they will believe you? I will do nothing unless you help me now. What are you going to do, shoot me? It will be a blessing. Go ahead shoot. I will pay you to shoot my family. You can do nothing to me!
answer: You will tell them I did nothing.
